articles.headline: A Big, and Risky, Energy Bet
articles.snippet: Sasol, a South African company, plans to take advantage of a glut of cheap gas to make diesel and other refined products at competitive prices in Louisiana.
articles.abstract: Sasol, a South African company, plans to take advantage of a glut of cheap gas to make diesel and other refined products at competitive prices in Louisiana.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAS LAFFAN INDUSTRIAL CITY, Qatar — The compact assembly of towers, tubes and tanks that make up the Oryx natural gas processing plant is almost lost in a vast petrochemical complex that rises here like a hazy mirage from a vast ocean of sand.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: As Europe Presses Google on Antitrust, U.S. Backs Away
articles.snippet: Google appears to be emerging from an major antitrust investigation in the United States essentially unscathed. But the outlook is not as bright for Google in Europe.
articles.abstract: Google appears to be emerging from an major antitrust investigation in the United States essentially unscathed. But the outlook is not as bright for Google in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Google seems on its way to coming through a major antitrust investigation in the United States essentially unscathed. But the outlook is not as bright for Google here, as the European Union’s top antitrust regulator prepares to meet on Tuesday with Eric E. Schmidt, Google’s executive chairman.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Massachusetts Fines Morgan Stanley Over Facebook I.P.O.
articles.snippet: The regulator, William F. Galvin, the Massachusetts secretary of the commonwealth, accused the bank of improperly influencing the I.P.O. process.
articles.abstract: The regulator, William F. Galvin, the Massachusetts secretary of the commonwealth, accused the bank of improperly influencing the I.P.O. process.
articles.lead_paragraph: 10:48 a.m. | Updated Morgan Stanley is paying for its role in the troubled stock market debut of Facebook.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Ben Protess

articles.headline: 2 Former Hedge Fund Managers Found Guilty in Insider Trading Case
articles.snippet: Anthony Chiasson, a co-founder of Level Global Investors, and Todd Newman, a former portfolio manager at Diamondback Capital Management, were found guilty on charges that they participated in a conspiracy that made more than $70 million illegally ...
articles.abstract: Anthony Chiasson, a co-founder of Level Global Investors, and Todd Newman, a former portfolio manager at Diamondback Capital Management, were found guilty on charges that they participated in a conspiracy that made more than $70 million illegally trading technology stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two former hedge fund managers were found guilty on Monday of fraud and conspiracy, the latest convictions in the government’s campaign to eliminate illegal conduct on Wall Street trading floors.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and William Alden

articles.headline: Banks Seek a Shield in Mortgage Rules
articles.snippet: As mortgage rules under the Dodd-Frank Act are finished, banks and policy makers want legal protections against lawsuits, while others worry that this will deny borrowers a critical safeguard.
articles.abstract: As mortgage rules under the Dodd-Frank Act are finished, banks and policy makers want legal protections against lawsuits, while others worry that this will deny borrowers a critical safeguard.
articles.lead_paragraph: As regulators complete new mortgage rules, banks are about to get a significant advantage: protection against homeowner lawsuits.

articles.headline: How Wal-Mart Used Payoffs to Get Its Way in Mexico
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart de Mexico was an aggressive and creative corrupter, offering large payoffs to get what the law otherwise prohibited, an examination by The New York Times found.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart de Mexico was an aggressive and creative corrupter, offering large payoffs to get what the law otherwise prohibited, an examination by The New York Times found.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN TEOTIHUACÁN, Mexico — Wal-Mart longed to build in Elda Pineda’s alfalfa field. It was an ideal location, just off this town’s bustling main entrance and barely a mile from its ancient pyramids, which draw tourists from around the world. With its usual precision, Wal-Mart calculated it would attract 250 customers an hour if only it could put a store in Mrs. Pineda’s field.
articles.byline: By David Barstow and Alejandra Xanic von Bertrab

articles.headline: Obama’s New Offer on Fiscal Crisis Could Lead to Deal
articles.snippet: President Obama delivered to Speaker John A. Boehner a new offer that would raise revenues by $1.2 trillion over 10 years but maintain tax rates for any household earning below $400,000.
articles.abstract: President Obama delivered to Speaker John A. Boehner a new offer that would raise revenues by $1.2 trillion over 10 years but maintain tax rates for any household earning below $400,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama delivered to Speaker John A. Boehner a new offer on Monday to resolve the pending fiscal crisis, a deal that would raise revenues by $1.2 trillion over the next decade but keep in place the Bush-era tax rates for any household with earnings below $400,000.

articles.headline: Pro-Gun Democrats Signaling Openness to Limits
articles.snippet: In the aftermath of the Connecticut school killings, momentum was building on Capitol Hill for tightening controls over firearms.
articles.abstract: In the aftermath of the Connecticut school killings, momentum was building on Capitol Hill for tightening controls over firearms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Demonstrating rapidly shifting attitudes toward gun control in the aftermath of a massacre in a Connecticut school, many pro-gun Congressional Democrats — including Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader and a longstanding gun rights supporter — signaled an openness Monday to new restrictions on guns.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Wall Street, Invested in Firearms, Is Unlikely to Push for Reform
articles.snippet: The private equity sector has stakes in some major gun makers, and taking the lead after the shootings in Newtown, Conn., could endanger firms’ own profits.
articles.abstract: The private equity sector has stakes in some major gun makers, and taking the lead after the shootings in Newtown, Conn., could endanger firms’ own profits.

articles.headline: Party Identity in a Gun Cabinet
articles.snippet: Whether someone owns a gun is a more powerful predictor of a person’s political party than gender, sexual orientation or many other demographic traits.
articles.abstract: Whether someone owns a gun is a more powerful predictor of a person’s political party than gender, sexual orientation or many other demographic traits.
articles.lead_paragraph: An American child grows up in a married household in the suburbs. What are the chances that his family keeps a gun in their home?

articles.headline: In Unusual Move, Cerberus to Sell Gun Company
articles.snippet: The private equity giant will sell its investment in the gun maker after a rifle from the company’s Bushmaster brand was used by the gunman in the school shootings in Connecticut.
articles.abstract: The private equity giant will sell its investment in the gun maker after a rifle from the company’s Bushmaster brand was used by the gunman in the school shootings in Connecticut.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sitting in their offices high above Park Avenue late on Monday, the private equity executives who own the country’s largest gun company received a phone call from one of their most influential investors.
